content: I had another good question in a tutorial today - can the meta.profile be a relative URI? I couldn't see why not but it just didn't seem right to me. There is a lot of talk about canonical in the spec, but it doesn't actually say whether we expect a data element of the canonical datatype to be an absolute URI or whether it is allowed to be relative.

Hi @Jean Duteau, canonical urls must be globally unique and (therefore) absolute:
http://hl7.org/fhir/structuredefinition-definitions.html#StructureDefinition.url
In theory, systems could accept relative urls within a limited scope (e.g. dev environment), as long as they are unique within that scope. However for published conformance resources, canonical urls must be absolute. Use a domain that is under your control, e.g. your company url. For examples resources, it is common practice to use "example.org".
how did they think a relative URI would work? Are they confusing canonical URI, which don't need to be resolvable into human form by a browser, from a web link that is?

The official source of truth on this is:

http://build.fhir.org/resource-definitions.html#Meta.profile which says, "The URL is a reference to StructureDefinition.url."

and http://build.fhir.org/structuredefinition-definitions.html#StructureDefinition.url which says, "An absolute URI that is used to identify this structure definition..."
So the short answer to your tutorial question is "no" :)
(Agreeing with Michel here; just trying to spell out the chain of investigation.)
Thanks @Michel Rutten I told the class that they had to be absolute but I couldn't find anything in the spec that backed me up. Your link is exactly what I needed.
